IT infrastructure in an on-premise

let's let's think of that as a step
function of some sort when you go to use
your IT infrastructure in on-premise
world you know that your usage is quite
variable it's not a straight line it's
not a step function and you're gonna
have this up and down variants
throughout the course of the year this
gives you two problems so one you get an
opportunity cost and this is where your
usage hasn't quite hit your demand
you've actually over invested for that
period of time you could have done
something better with that money
potentially but you instead you're stuck
with unutilized IT equipment on the flip
side you get this lost opportunity and
this is where the opposite happens this
is where you might have this unexpected
project or a sudden customer demand or a

and you haven't got the capacity to to
do that you've gotta wait you might have
to put a project on hold for another
financial year it's a very common
scenario that our customers face who are
on on-premises environments and this
kind of phenomena happens regardless of
how efficiently you manage on-premise
this is just something inherent with
running on-premise and it's not the
fault of people who are running these
environments so I guess the economics of
AWS and moving to cloud is all about
getting that supply and demand line as
close as possible so you starting to see
that elimination of wastage and you're
trying to make sure that we get those
supply and demand lines as close as
possible so that you can continue to use
the platform for the demand that you
need and for that unexpected demand when
it comes through so there are a number
of ways that AWS takes this concept and
applies it to help you reduce costs the
first is around our pricing models and
we'll go through these in a second
but we've got three different pricing
models to suit your different workloads
the second is around giving you levers
to remove wastage and making sure that
you pay only for what you need
the third is around proactive price
reduction so AWS has a culture of doing
proactive price reductions and we've
done 72 price reductions since our
inception in 2006 and finally as you
grow you're going to get more access to
tiered volume and pricing discounts and
various things that so as you grow it
becomes cheaper to sort of do business
with AWS
so three and four up there are things
that you'll get as a result of being on
AWS but the first two are sort of
techniques and skills that you can use
to actually get the most out of the
platform and I'm gonna talk you through
these techniques so we call them levers
and the first lever is around picking
the right pricing model we've got three
different pricing models as I mentioned
before on demand reserved instances and
spot on demand is your sort of classic
cloud computing where you're paying by
the hour by the minute and in fact we
build a lot of on-demand services by the
second and you've got no commitment to
us beyond that time period I'm so very
flexible no commute type of model
reserved instances you do commit for one
or three years but in result in exchange
for that commitment we give you a pretty
substantial discount in the case of a
three-year reserved instances discounts
can be up to sixty five percent versus
on-demand so it is pretty substantial
for that commitment and finally you have
spot and spotters are much more of a
dynamic pricing model we set pricing on
a pretty dynamic basis based on
historical supply and demand and you can
you can bid for that capacity based on
what you need and and it's it is much
more dynamic you can get significantly
higher discounts versus on demand but of
course we reserve the right to change
the prices within a two-hour window so
the way you use that it is very
dependent on your particular workload
the next level we have around
cost-savings is the concept called right
sizing and right sizing is all about
understanding your utilization and
making sure that you only utilize what
you sorry you only provision on AWS what
in fact you're actually utilizing so as
an example if you've got a 4 V CPU 16
gigabyte of RAM machine running on
premise if you weren't gonna right size
this and we're going to think about
utilization this would be what's called
in AWS terms as a c5 x-large which is on
demand it's a 22 cents per hour instance
a typical utilization is around that 40
50 percent based on what statistics
we've seen globally so if you were to
apply that to that 4 V CPU 16 gigabyte
of RAM virtual machine that would
straightaway map to a c5 dot large and
you'd save 50 percent of your bill just
by doing that so utilization is an
important part to make sure that you
understand and when you're building your
business cases use that utilization as a
way to control the cost and on AWS the
third lever is a concept call elasticity
elasticity to put it quite simply is
just turning your instances off when
you're not using it and a classic
example of elasticity and benefiting
from elasticity is test dev a lot of our
customers run test observers 100% of the
time even though they only use that
during office hours and if you actually
use AWS the test dev and you're turning
servers when you when turning them off
when you're not using them you can get
some significant discounts by simply not
paying for them when they're not on you
can get a lot more sophisticated with
elasticity we have tools like Auto scale
where you can set rules to provision
when your capacity scales up and scales
down and we also have a service called
AWS lambda which is our service
computing and you only actually pay for
your resources when the code is running
and no other cost so again all work load
dependent and application dependent I'm
not suggesting you can do this for every
single application but it's definitely
something to consider when you're
building your business case
so when you actually flow this through
all these three levers are quite
compounding in the way that they sort of
stack up and add value so let's just

you've put everything on demand and you

perhaps the most important interesting
